comments.content: That's incorrect - the given answer is correct. Bridges typically only have 2 ports
The file server is in a different building, the 23 users and 2 printers are located in the office area.

discussion.content: Just because it is in a different building, I will go with bridge

questions.question_text: A network technician is required to install a network device to provide service to an office area. The office area has 23 users and two printers that must be able to connect to the file server in a different building. Which of the following network devices should the technician use?

discussion.content:
My opinion.
D would be if point-to-point or point-to-site is asked as it is a temporary tunnel.
Site-to-site is permanent connection and it is designed as dedicated route
It says long term so, I believe the answer is correct.

comments.content:
How secure are VPN tunnels?
A VPN tunnel is an encrypted connection between your device and a VPN server. It's uncrackable without a cryptographic key, i will go with C

discussion.content:
btw...searching on google:

"What is key rotation policy?
Key rotation is when you retire an encryption key and replace that old key by generating a new cryptographic key. Rotating keys on a regular basis help meet industry standards and cryptographic best practices. ... If a key is rotated every day, only that day of information can be decrypted by the attacker."


so it the key is changed annually, I do not think it will work...so I will go with D. And if anyone has a better explanation, please let me know

choices.C: Perform annual key rotations on the site-to-site VPNs.
choices.B: Request a change of IP addresses from the ISP semiannually.
choices.D: Terminate tunnels when they are not actively being used.
choices.A: Purchase dedicated MPLS circuits between each of the sites.

questions.question_text: A company has multiple site-to-site VPN connections using a pre-shared key. The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is concerned about the long-term security of the tunnels and has asked the network technicians to develop a plan to ensure the best security of the tunnels. Which of the following should the network technicians implement?

discussion.content: FHRP - designed to protect the default gateway used on a subnetwork by allowing two or more routers to provide backup for that address;

questions.question_text: Which of the following technologies provides a failover mechanism for the default gateway?

discussion.content: Going with Star here. Yes, the N10-007 test is "old" and about to be retired, but it came out in 2018. We weren't using 10Base5 and 10Base2 in 2018, we were using ETHERNET. Bus is the simplest and the traditional topology, but it was based on coax cable. The question states ETHERNET. When using twisted pair cable or fiber optical cable, the topology is Star.

comments.content: The test is old and on its way to retirement. When this was written, 2021 was in the future.

discussion.content:
Show me the majority of the population that has device connected to device in a bus topology instead of having all the devices connect directly to the gateway. 
It's 2021, the majority of LANs use start topologies.

" physical topology for an Ethernet LAN"
Did they mention router or switch or even a hub ? 
it's simply bus topology
This answer is definitely supposed to be Star.

Why bus .? Not star
Star
Star topology has become the dominant physical topology for LANs. The star was first popularized by ARCNET, and later adopted by Ethernet.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/computer-science/physical-topology

This is a strange question. From what I understand, most Ethernet LANs use either Bus or Star topologies. I thought Bus was more common so I went with that, but I doubt anyone could say that "Star is not a real physical topology for Ethernet LAN"
Asnswer supposed to be D. Star

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the physical topology for an Ethernet LAN?

discussion.content: Nic Teaming - The major benefits of NIC teaming are load balancing (redistributing traffic over networks) and failover (ensuring network continuity in the event of system hardware failure) without the need for multiple physical connections

Network Interface Card (NIC) teaming allows you to combine multiple physical network adapters into a virtual NIC, which will then be presented to the OS as a single NIC. All of the traffic being sent from the OS will pass through the virtual NIC and be load-balanced across the assigned physical network connections
